questions.question_text: Which of the following should be replaced after a voltage spike?

discussion.content: A. Surge suppressor
Surge suppressors take the damage from the blow which is why they get replaced.

https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/surge-suppressor-surge-protector#:~:text=A%20surge%20suppressor%20(sometimes%20optimistically,voltage%20%22spikes%22%20called%20transients.
I think surge suppressor is same as surge protector, so the answer is A.

Selected Answer: A
Just googled it. 
The general rule of thumb, however, is that surge protectors should be replaced after small numbers of large voltage spikes or large numbers of small spikes. Degraded components can render your surge protector uselessâ€”and even increase the threat of fire.
I don't get why does this need to be replaced if it doesn't say it broke?
the surge suppressor was used prior to this power spike so the psu needs to replace.

According to Google a surge suppressor (sometimes optimistically called a "surge protector") is a device inserted in the alternating current ( AC ) utility line and/or telephone line to prevent damage to electronic equipment from voltage "spikes" called transients
surge protector and surge suppressor are two different this things so i think the answer C is correct

comments.content: they are 2 of the same things that utilize different technology to accomplish the same thing. avoid electrical surges to fry your component.

discussion.content: is a surge suppressor the same thing as a surge protector? because if so, it should definitely be surge protector

questions.question_text:
A technician is working on an infected computer that is currently turned off. The technician is concerned the boot sector is affected.
Which of the following is the BEST method for the technician to use to scan the boot sector?

choices.A: Mount the drive using a forensic platform.
choices.C: Boot to last known good configuration.
choices.D: Boot the drive in another computer.

discussion.content: Idk mahn fok
Why not boot into safe mode and remove the virus since safe mode without internet.
holy hell, forensic platform isn't even on entirety of A+lmao
Can CompTIA stop with these stupid questions already?

comments.content: Somewhere you can scan and inspect the drive safely. You can't just move it into another PC and mount it or you risk the infection spreading. So instead you can mount it via a "forensic platform" that will allow you to scan the drive without the risk of the infection spreading further into your system. For a basic example you could redirect a usb port to a virtual machine and inspect it in there, that way if there is an infection that spreads it will only affect the virtual machine and not anything else. (Please don't try this unless you are sure you know what you're doing, there IS malware out there that can escape VM's and cause you some real problems.)
i don't see any forensic platform on the objective.

discussion.content: What is a forensic platform?!

questions.question_text:
A user in a SOHO wants to allow Joe, a remote technician, to connect securely to the user's workstation. Joe informs the user that the VPN was successful, but he still cannot connect.
Which of the following settings in the SOHO router MOST likely need to be adjusted?

discussion.content: The VPN connection is successful. There is no issue with the connection to the SOHO device. Something is blocking the inbound traffic from there. The best option is firewall.
Why it is not DHCP if the DHCP is selected the IP address will be changed whenever the pc is turned on, and then Static IP would be great in my opinion because it won't change.

comments.content: Set up a firewall along with a VPN
The logic makes sense. (A) was feeling right, but the permission i get but since it's moved... users may not have access to it or parts of it.

discussion.content:
The most likely reasons the users cannot connect are because of denied permissions and mapped drives. If the data was moved to another computer, the folders will inherit new permissions from the parent (by default). That will most likely eliminate the current user access. Also, the path to the share will change (again by default). Either the server name/IP address, the sharename, or both will be different when the data is moved to another server. So, to fix the problem, the user and group permissions will have to be modified for the new share, and new mapped drives will need to be configured. 
--Quentin Doctor Practice Exam Cram Core 2

Denied write/delete permissions would not leave users unable to read files like the question states. Option A seems a more likely fit that D. If the files are moved to a specific user account folder or a different machine then users may need to be added to the local admin group to access it. This is more true if the new drive or parent folder requires admin permissions/group-membership to read because moving files across drives changes the files permissions to inherit from the destination. In the case of a permissions conflict Windows will default to most restrictive.
So A B would be my choice. I'm interested to hear other arguments.

Selected Answer: AB
A and B

The questions also states they have proper security and access. But that data was moved to another server, so hence mapping to different drive? Maybe they have the same permissions, that were on the previous but not modified for the new additional server?
For those commenting on users not having access... re-read the question " The technician confirms the users are all in the proper security groups and have the proper access"

comments.content: Even if they are in the same security group each user may have different permissions

discussion.content: I think it should be : A & B

questions.question_text:
A SOHO technician recently moved some data from one server to another to increase storage capacity. Several users are now reporting they cannot access certain shares on the network. When the users attempt to access the shares, they get the following error: Access Denied. The technician confirms the users are all in the proper security groups and have the proper access, but they are still unable to access the shares.
Which of the following are the MOST likely reasons for these issues? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: C is correct.How would we pass an exam if they give us lots of wrong answer.

A is the correct answer
Unlocked padlock with yellow warning triangle: BitLocker is inactive or the protection is temporarily suspended: Hard Drive is encrypted but everyone has access. This icon is also used to indicate the BitLocker is pre-provisioned.

https://www.tenforums.com/tutorials/38508-suspend-resume-bitlocker-protection-drive-windows-10-a.html

Bitlocker is suspended

A correct...
Unlocked padlock with yellow warning triangle: BitLocker is inactive or the protection is temporarily suspended: Hard Drive is encrypted but everyone has access. This icon is also used to indicate the BitLocker is pre-provisioned.

Unlocked padlock with yellow warning triangle: BitLocker is inactive or the protection is temporarily suspended: Hard Drive is encrypted but everyone has access. This icon is also used to indicate the BitLocker is pre-provisioned. You can resume the BitLocker on the drive or disable the BitLocker for the drive to remove the icon.
would go with C

I think it is A but the answer is not correctly worded:
Unlocked padlock with yellow warning triangle: BitLocker is suspended: Drive is encrypted but everyone has access. This icon is also used to indicate the BitLocker is pre-provisioned.

comments.content:
I agree with what is said here, but I would go with C. Both A and C are incorrect based on how they are worded. But as you said, the icon indicates Bitlocker is suspended, so I believe C is the closest to correct. A is totally wrong in my opinion because Bitlocker is operating on the system for everyone. Including the user.

Hopefully the wording is fixed on the actual test

choices.B: BitLocker has locked the drive, and it is no longer accessible.
choices.D: BitLocker has encountered an error, and the user should run the check disk utility.
choices.C: BitLocker is suspended, and the drive is no longer encrypted.
choices.A: BitLocker is operating on the system but not for the user.

questions.question_text:
A computer running Windows 7 has an icon that has the appearance of an unlocked padlock with a yellow warning graphic.
This icon advises the user that:
